texts.definition: A level is a part of the game in which all player action takes place until a certain goal has been reached or an end condition has been fulfilled.
markups: <style="Definition">A level is a part of the game in which all player action takes place until a certain goal has been reached or an end condition has been fulfilled.</style>

One way that games can divide gameplay into separate sections or chunks are to spatially constrain players into different parts of the game world. These separate parts are typically called <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style>.

The difference between Levels in a game may be in content, aesthetics, or a combination of both. Commonly used differences between levels in early arcade games, such as Missile Command, are different color themes and speed of enemy units, thereby creating different levels of difficulty. By contrast, most of the current first-person shooters and real-time strategy games have new environments to be explored in each level, i. e., each level presents new enemies and puzzles for the player. In some games, the levels can also have different primary activities the player has to perform repetitively.

Note: ''this pattern is not about the concept of character development through 'Levels'. That concept is described in the pattern <style="Link"><link="character-levels">Character Levels</link></style>.''
<style="H3">Examples</style>

Many early computer games included <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> but where the difference was only in theme or difficulty if there was any difference at all. Examples of such games include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asteroids">Asteroids</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pac-Man">Pac-Man</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Missile%20Command">Missile Command</link></style> and the primary use of <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> in these games are to signify progression and repopulate the game world, and this is still found in some puzzle games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bejeweled">Bejeweled</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Staries">Staries</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zoo%20Keeper">Zoo Keeper</link></style>. However, many other puzzle games have different configurations or game elements to offer new challenges. Examples of this include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Braid">Braid</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Continuity">Continuity</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Cogs">Cogs</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Incredible%20Machine%20game%20series">Incredible Machine game series</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sokoban">Sokoban</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Portal%20series">Portal series</link></style>. Other computer games that make use of <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> to offer new challenges include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Marble%20Madness">Marble Madness</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mercury%20Meltdown">Mercury Meltdown</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Lemmings%20series">Lemmings series</link></style>, as well as racing games such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Gran%20Turismo%20series">Gran Turismo series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Need%20for%20Speed%20series">Need for Speed series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Wipeout%20series">Wipeout series</link></style>.

Many other computer games use <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> to gradually increase the difficulty while at the same time developing a story of sorts. Examples of this include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Legend%20of%20Zelda%20series">The Legend of Zelda series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario%20series">Super Mario series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Doom%20series">Doom series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NetHack">NetHack</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diablo%20series">Diablo series</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style>.

Computer games with large game worlds sometimes use <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> to handle issues of system resources and keeping various monsters and non-player characters from moving freely. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Elder%20Scrolls%20series">The Elder Scrolls series</link></style> and

the Fallout series are examples of such games. The instances found in some Massively Multiplayer Online Games, e.g. World of Warcraft, can be seen as a similar form of Levels. These allow subsets of the players logged on to particular servers to together try to complete specially designed challenges without interference or support from others; in fact several different groups can be in their own instance of the same Level and have no effect on each other, and this is the source of the name for the game concept. It should be noted though that players often have the possibility to leave these Levels without completing some goal.

Although not as common as in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer%20Games">Computer Games</link></style>, some <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Games</link></style> can be seen as making use of <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style>. Examples of this includes the missions of both <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Alert">Space Alert</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Hulk">Space Hulk</link></style>, which are described as part of a larger story even if each game instance only typically makes use of one of the <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style>. The dungeons found in many <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> can be seen as weak examples of <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> - they are often described as such in supplements but in many cases players could leave them whenever they wish.
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

When implementing <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> in a game, game designers must decide how many <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> the game contains, how they differ and relate to each other, and if they are parts of a larger <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> (e.g. through <style="Link"><link="instances">Instances</link></style>) or constitute the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style>. Another aspect is how much <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> is to be used in the creation of the <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> for each game instance (one reason may be to try and provide more <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style>). Whenever <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> is used the option of letting players provide <style="Link"><link="explicit-random-seeds">Explicit Random Seeds</link></style> emerges which can allow players to choose between having <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> or replaying specific setups. While most of the comments about how <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> can be designed below assume that these are created by game designers, games such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Advance%20Wars%20series">Advance Wars series</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/LittleBigPlanet">LittleBigPlanet</link></style> have built-in support for players to create and share <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> as a form of <style="Link"><link="player-created-game-elements">Player Created Game Elements</link></style>. An alternative is to create algorithms that create <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style>, making them into <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Procedurally%20Generated%20Game%20Areas">Procedurally Generated Game Areas</link></style> (and typically meaning that <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> becomes a big part of designing the <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style>). While <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> are usually designed as a continuum of the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> populated with game elements, they can also be created from <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style> (this is done for example in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Hulk">Space Hulk</link></style>). <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> can be created through creating <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style>.

Themes are an easy way to differentiate <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> (see diegetic aspects below) but this needs to be tied to changed gameplay if this should not just be an visual difference. Another way to differentiate between <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> is by changing the end conditions and the primary activities of the players. Having different types of goals that require different fields of expertise guarantees <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style> and includes the possibility of having <style="Link"><link="unknown-goals">Unknown Goals</link></style> as the player progresses from <style="CurrentLink">level</style> to <style="CurrentLink">level</style>. This either increases what is required for having <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> of a game or requires flexibility to be part of <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="ever-increasing-difficulty">Ever Increasing Difficulty</link></style> can be added to a game by steadily making <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> more difficult; combine with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Procedurally%20Generated%20Game%20Areas">Procedurally Generated Game Areas</link></style> this can be true past any players ability to complete <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style>, otherwise it ends when finishing the game.

The combination of theme, end condition, and primary activities sets the boundaries for what diegetic game elements should be used in a given level. The use of game elements such as <style="Link"><link="alarms">Alarms</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="props">Props</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="big-dumb-objects">Big Dumb Objects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="controllers">Controllers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="helpers">Helpers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="installations">Installations</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="landmarks">Landmarks</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="pick-ups">Pick-Ups</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Resource%20Generators">Resource Generators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="self-service-kiosks">Self-Service Kiosks</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="switches">Switches</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style> are all common. These, and the spatial relationships between them such as <style="Link"><link="laning">Laning</link></style>, can be used to subdivide the <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> into areas with distinctively different gameplay, including <style="Link"><link="arenas">Arenas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="choke-points">Choke Points</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="flanking-routes">Flanking Routes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="galleries">Galleries</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="safe-havens">Safe Havens</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="secret-areas">Secret Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="sniper-locations">Sniper Locations</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Strongholds">Strongholds</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="transport-routes">Transport Routes</link></style>. Of course, they may also make them into <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style>. Designing parts of <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> to be traversed mainly by <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style> can make them into <style="Link"><link="vehicle-sections">Vehicle Sections</link></style>.

Many of these are inherently <style="Link"><link="strategic-locations">Strategic Locations</link></style> while others can become this due to rarity or their position in relation to other game elements. In addition, using different setups can provide further <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style>. In addition to these diegetic elements, <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> can be populated with non-diegetic elements such as <style="Link"><link="geospatial-game-widgets">Geospatial Game Widgets</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="check-points">Check Points</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="save-points">Save Points</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="spawn-points">Spawn Points</link></style>, of which the latter provide the possibility of <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style> during gameplay on the <style="CurrentLink">Level</style>. Where <style="Link"><link="spawning">Spawning</link></style> of players' <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> occur is especially important as this determines the starting conditions for the players, and this can be used to create <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> if it puts them in danger from their very appearance - this can be avoid by putting the <style="Link"><link="spawn-points">Spawn Points</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="safe-havens">Safe Havens</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="warp-zones">Warp Zones</link></style> can be created both as abstract entities or <style="Link"><link="installations">Installations</link></style>, and can be used to either connect together different parts of the <style="CurrentLink">Level</style> or provide the means to move to other <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style>. <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style> can be used to draw players' attention to any of these elements in the <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style>, or to draw them towards <style="Link"><link="red-herrings">Red Herrings</link></style>.

The use of <style="Link"><link="territories">Territories</link></style> can be used to shift focus partly from what is happening in the <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> to the attributes of the actual <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style>.

There are some options for <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> that affect the overall travel through them. The first is the option to let them be <style="Link"><link="backtracking-levels">Backtracking Levels</link></style>, that is <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> that one first moves through and then has to move back through. The second, which is a way is an opposite, is to provide <style="Link"><link="quick-returns">Quick Returns</link></style> so that players do not have to go through parts of <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> they have already been in unless they wish to do so. <style="Link"><link="setback-penalties">Setback Penalties</link></style> can be used to make players traverse <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style>, or parts of them, due to some failure on their part. Of course, one can introduce <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style> goals besides the one typically present of getting to the end of a <style="CurrentLink">Level</style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Automated%20Responses">Automated Responses</link></style> when entering <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> can give players a presentation of the them before actual gameplay begins.

The spatial construction of <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> affect how players can be made aware of the existence of further <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style>, and how they perceive that they can reach them. Being able to directly observe the other levels through <style="Link"><link="invisible-walls">Invisible Walls</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style> is an obvious way to do this, but <style="Link"><link="game-state-overviews">Game State Overviews</link></style> as well as <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="helpers">Helpers</link></style> can also be used. The latter option is in some cases easier to fit within the <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> of the game. Providing several different <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> played can chose to play, found for example in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario%20series">Super Mario series</link></style>, gives players a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style>. However, it is very common to open up <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> for play through <style="Link"><link="facilitating-rewards">Facilitating Rewards</link></style>, of which the simplest form is probably the ordering of <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> in a sequence and making the completion of one <style="CurrentLink">Level</style> the requirement for opening up the next <style="CurrentLink">Level</style> in the sequence for gameplay. While <style="Link"><link="facilitating-rewards">Facilitating Rewards</link></style> can be used to automatically move players to new <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style>, <style="Link"><link="access-rewards">Access Rewards</link></style> can be used instead to open up for players to choose which <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> to attempt next.

Game designers can with relative surety make <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> have <style="Link"><link="casual-gameplay">Casual</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> since they can decide on a quite exact level what types of challenges the players will met. This can be used to create <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style> by making the first <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> small or easy so that players can get familiar with interfaces and core gameplay, and when they have completed these they can proceed with more challenging ones.

A common effect of finishing a <style="CurrentLink">Level</style> is the <style="Link"><link="quick-travel">Quick Travel</link></style> to another <style="CurrentLink">Level</style>, and this is typically also a form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/One-Way%20Travel">One-Way Travel</link></style>. While simply reacting a specific location may be enough to change level, the use of <style="Link"><link="conditional-passageways">Conditional Passageways</link></style> can tie the completion of <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> to other goals than just <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style>. This may be done through <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Events</link></style> when the end condition for completing the <style="CurrentLink">Level</style> has been reached, or be activated by players by the use of a <style="Link"><link="warp-zones">Warp Zone</link></style> - the latter can allow players the possibility to handle <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> and collecting of <style="Link"><link="loot">Loot</link></style> before moving on to the next <style="CurrentLink">Level</style>.
<style="H3">Diegetic Aspects</style>

As for <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, both <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> affect how players perceive <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style>. In contrast to <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> however, <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> can also help create <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> since they can show imply larger <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> than are shown by representing different parts of them. Being limited parts of these <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> provide natural points for creating <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style> goals. Finishing <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style> goals are often symbolized by the activation of a <style="Link"><link="controllers">Controller</link></style>, such as opening the main door to the next level, or by defeating a <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monster</link></style>. Regardless of what specific goals are used in a <style="CurrentLink">Level</style>, game designer creating <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> need to consider how players should be able to do <style="Link"><link="game-world-navigation">Game World Navigation</link></style> (<style="Link"><link="big-dumb-objects">Big Dumb Objects</link></style> can play roles here), and between which parts of the <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> the exists <style="Link"><link="line-sight">Line of Sight</link></style>. Optionally, one may consider if one should actively design to support <style="Link"><link="speedruns">Speedruns</link></style>.

In order to be perceived as part of the same game, <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> need not only share the same core gameplay but also have <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> between them. As the change from one <style="CurrentLink">Level</style> to another typically signifies a change from one location to another, this can be used as a means to change theme, e.g. from a forest to a cave or from a railway station to a factory. The theme can then be used to set the boundaries for how much the <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> can be stressed; changing the theme too much to introduce new gameplay can however become an example of <style="Link"><link="alien-space-bats">Alien Space Bats</link></style>.

The design of a part of a <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> through <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> can of course also be used to create <style="Link"><link="environmental-storytelling">Environmental Storytelling</link></style>.
<style="H3">Interface Aspects</style>

<style="Link"><link="mini">Mini-maps</link></style> are quite common interface tools to help with the <style="Link"><link="game-world-navigation">Game World Navigation</link></style> of <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Level%20Summaries">Level Summaries</link></style> can be used after a <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> are completed to provide players with information on how well they completed the <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> both regarding required and <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goals</link></style>.
<style="H3">Narrative Aspects</style>

Unless created completely by <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> are <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> and can thereby be used to progress a narrative as gameplay progresses like <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style> can. <style="Link"><link="finale-levels">Finale Levels</link></style> are <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> specifically design to create a more important narrative closure (i.e. more important that simply the completion of the <style="CurrentLink">Level</style>), e.g. the encountering of a <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monster</link></style>. In other cases, present <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="environmental-storytelling">Environmental Storytelling</link></style> can be more likely to be encountered by players through how they are herded through the <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style>.
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> are basically <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style> with well-defined boundaries. As such, they let game designers delimit <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> and thereby the complexity of the game - especially for <style="Link"><link="game-world-navigation">Game World Navigation</link></style> - as well as giving players <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Foresight">Limited Foresight</link></style>. The also bring natural <style="Link"><link="closure-points">Closure Points</link></style> since they have an end, and this is especially noticeable when leaving a <style="CurrentLink">Level</style> is an <style="Link"><link="irreversible-events">Irreversible Event</link></style>. In games with <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style>, this typically means restricting that <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> to a <style="CurrentLink">Level</style> until it is completed.

In games with <style="Link"><link="hotseating">Hotseating</link></style>, the completion of a <style="CurrentLink">Level</style> can be a natural point for a new player to take over playing the game. <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> can also be used to progress the <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> in a controlled fashion since they can be <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> and make the rest of a <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> into <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style>. This can be used to make the <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> into <style="Link"><link="campaigns">Campaigns</link></style>, as for example the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Advance%20Wars%20series">Advance Wars series</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Memoir%20'44">Memoir '44</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> does.

Besides what actually take place in the <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style>, this progression of stories can be done through <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style> between the <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style>. Since entering new <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> put players in contact with new game elements, they can provide <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style> into the game seen as a whole.

Except when used as smaller part of a <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> (as for example <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Elder%20Scrolls%20series">The Elder Scrolls series</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style> does), the existence of a <style="CurrentLink">Level</style> assumes the existence of a next <style="CurrentLink">Level</style> or the completion of the game. This provides explicit short-term <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style> goals of finding the next <style="CurrentLink">Level</style>. The completion of a level thereby provides strong <style="Link"><link="hovering-closures">Hovering Closures</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style>, and the former can be increased further if <style="Link"><link="save-points">Save Points</link></style> only exist between the <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style>. These types of <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> create <style="Link"><link="goal-hierarchies">Goal Hierarchies</link></style> and provide a form of <style="Link"><link="access-rewards">Access Rewards</link></style>, be it linear, as is the case with the many <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">First-Person Shooters</link></style> such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Doom%20series">Doom series</link></style>, or structured in a more elaborate way, as is done for example in the different worlds in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario%20series">Super Mario series</link></style>.

By being different both as to structure and gameplay, <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> can provide <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style>. Combined with <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="switches">Switches</link></style> this can become <style="Link"><link="varying-rule-sets">Varying Rule Sets</link></style> and only some rules apply on some <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style>. <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> partly or wholly created through <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> can vary gameplay further and in this can also supports <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style> (as for example in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NetHack">NetHack</link></style>). <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> also have the possibility to support <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style> goals, the former which may be extended to a larger scale if players have a choice between the order in which to complete <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style>.

Movement between <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> create <style="Link"><link="quick-travel">Quick Travel</link></style> unless games are explicitly designed to not have this. One example of how this can be avoid is present in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> - here the safe rooms are present in both levels and changes occur when all doors are closed so the noticeable difference of having changed <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> is minimized.

<style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> can instantiate <style="Link"><link="extra-chances">Extra Chances</link></style> since they are portions of the whole gameplay in a game and failing one of them can be separate from failing the whole game.

Games with short <style="CurrentLink">Levels</style> that one complete through <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style> create <style="Link"><link="meta-games">Meta Games</link></style>. These support <style="Link"><link="negotiable-game-sessions">Negotiable Game Sessions</link></style> when the individual puzzles vary in amount time needed to complete them.
